The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. Subsections are reorganized to accommodate these new credits. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. The new subsection (e) introduces the New Flexible Fuel Hybrid Motor Vehicle Credit for taxpayers who place a new hybrid flexible fuel motor vehicle in service during the taxable year. The credit amount is determined according to a specified table. The credit amount for a vehicle with city fuel economy between 125-225% of a comparable vehicle ranges from $1,500 to $3,500. The city fuel economy of a vehicle for the credit is determined on an E-85 ethanol gallon equivalent basis, while the comparable vehicle's fuel economy is determined on a gasoline gallon equivalent basis. A new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle is defined as a qualified hybrid vehicle capable of running on alternative fuel, gasoline, or any blend, certified to achieve a city fuel economy using E-85 ethanol that is at least 125% of a comparable nonhybrid vehicle's city fuel economy on gasoline. The extension of termination for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles under subsection (k) of section 30B of the Code is amended to December 31, 2014. The extension of termination for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles under subsection (k) of section 30B of the Code is amended to December 31, 2014. Vehicles included in the numeric limitation are amended to include subsections (d) and (e). Conforming amendments are made to subsections (i)(5) and (i)(6) of the Code. The extension of termination for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles under subsection (k) of section 30B of the Code is amended to December 31, 2014. Amendments are made to subsection (k) regarding qualified hybrid motor vehicles. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2006.
